keyTakeAways: The Louvre museum in Paris remains closed due to a major heist involving the theft of historic royal jewelry, including a tiara and necklace from the Napoleonic era.
The robbers used a truck-mounted ladder to break into the Apollo Gallery through a window, armed with tools like an angle grinder and blowtorch, completing the heist in just seven minutes.

Among the stolen items is a diadem with 24 Ceylon sapphires and 1,083 diamonds, and an emerald necklace and earrings gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise in 1810, containing 32 emeralds and 1,138 diamonds.
Eight of the nine stolen items remain unaccounted for, raising concerns that the jewelry has been taken abroad and possibly melted down or sold on the black market.

Experts, including French senator Natalie Goulet and Art Recovery International founder Christopher Marinello, believe the jewelry is unlikely to be recovered and may have been used as a money-laundering mechanism by organized criminal groups.

The heist exposes serious security failures at the Louvre, with Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin stating that windows were unsecured and public infrastructure (like a basket lift) was not properly protected.
The incident is seen as a profound blow to French national identity and heritage, with author Elaine Sciolino calling it a 'dagger into the heart of France and French history.'

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Louvre museum in Paris has been closed following a brazen heist on October 19, 2025, in which thieves used a truck-mounted ladder to break into the Apollo Gallery through a window and stole several high-value historical jewelry pieces, including a diadem worn by Queen Marie-Amélie and an emerald necklace gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise. The entire operation took just seven minutes, with the robbers leaving on scooters by the Seine. Experts, including French senator Natalie Goulet and Art Recovery International founder Christopher Marinello, believe the jewelry has likely been taken abroad and melted down or sold on the black market as a means of laundering dirty money, indicating possible links to organized crime. French Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin admitted serious security failures, such as unsecured windows and public access to a basket lift. The theft has sparked widespread national grief and concern, with author Elaine Sciolino calling it a 'dagger into the heart of France and French history.' The incident echoes past museum thefts, such as the 1911 Mona Lisa heist and the 1998 theft of Camille Corot’s painting, underscoring ongoing vulnerabilities in museum security worldwide.
title: Looted Louvre Treasures May Never Be Found, Experts Say, as Museum Remains Closed
